summary: Email correspondence between Assistant U.S. Attorney A. Marie Villafaña and plaintiff's attorney Katherine W. Ezell regarding Jeffrey Epstein's work release conditions, specifically addressing victim safety concerns about Epstein's GPS monitoring and whether victims' addresses would be disclosed if programmed as off-limits.

persons.name: Katherine W. Ezell
persons.context: Attorney representing victims in the Epstein case, corresponding with the U.S. Attorney's office about safety concerns regarding Epstein's work release and GPS monitoring.

persons.name: A. Marie Villafaña
persons.context: Federal prosecutor corresponding with plaintiff's attorney about Epstein's work release conditions and victim safety protocols.

persons.name: Amy Eden
persons.context: Copied on the email correspondence between attorneys regarding Epstein's work release.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Subject of the correspondence; on work release with GPS monitoring, traveling between jail and office with a private driver.

connections.description: Attorney correspondence regarding victim safety concerns in the Epstein case.
Ezell represents victims against Epstein, expressing safety concerns about his work release.
Villafaña is the federal prosecutor handling Epstein's case and managing his work release conditions.

events.title: Email exchange about Epstein's work release
events.description: Correspondence between attorneys discussing Epstein's GPS monitoring, victim address protection, and work release procedures.

locations: 500 S. Australian Ave, Suite 400, West Palm Beach, FL 33401
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was on work release with GPS monitoring, traveling only between jail and an office with a private driver.
The Palm Beach Sheriff's Office (PBSO) programmed Epstein's travel routes into his GPS monitor and would check for deviations.
Victims could request their addresses be programmed as off-limits on Epstein's GPS device, with assurances the addresses would not be disclosed to Epstein or his people.
All requests for address restrictions had to go through A. Marie Villafaña to verify legitimacy.
